metadata.synopsis: Dialogue with the Orthon, where he tells you it was ordered by Raphael to kill Ketheric's Dark Justiciars. The dialogue ends in combat, unless you succeed some very hard persuasions.Orthon is huge, forboding and loves a good fight. He speaks in a low rumble and is TERRIFYING.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Walk to Orthon's gory throne at-646; -6; -754

121.context:
CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.

202.speaker: Yurgir
202.text: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.

67.speaker: Yurgir
67.text: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.

161.speaker: Yurgir
161.text: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?

143.speaker: Player
143.text: What do you know about infernal machinery?

3.speaker: Yurgir
3.text: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it.

169.speaker: Player
169.text: I don't serve Zariel. And I'm going up - not down.

188.speaker: Yurgir
188.text: Something tells me you aren't going anywhere at all. You must know it too, reeking of fear as you do.

216.speaker: Player
216.text: I'm never going back to Avernus. But I'd be happy to send you there.

31.speaker: Yurgir
31.text: Such high confidence for someone who reeks so distinctively of fear.

160.speaker: Yurgir
160.text: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? There's a whiff of the surface to you...
160.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Orthon sniffs the air before delivering line.InternalNodeContext: Tagged subnodes for:
- REALLY_UNDERDARK
- UNDERDARK/Not REALLY_UNDERDARK (ie disguised)
- UntaggedNodeContext: Sniffs the air just before speaking, as if detecting something,

173.speaker: Karlach
173.text: Holy shit. An orthon. Powerful devils - I wouldn't get on their bad side without a good reason.

257.speaker: Yurgir
257.text: You - tiefling. You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.

197.speaker: Yurgir
197.text: You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.

211.speaker: Karlach
211.text: What do you know of infernal machinery?
211.context: NodeContext: To the orthon. Adversarial, but she's hoping he knows something useful.

255.speaker: Yurgir
255.text: A new arrival, then. You burrowed too deep, little rabbit...

162.speaker: Player
162.text: Put that thing down. I'm here to talk.

140.speaker: Yurgir
140.text: I don't talk to prey, I -
140.context:
NodeContext: Scornful, but then breaks off before finishing the line
(Full version would be 'I don't talk to prey, I skin them' if he'd finished it)

127.speaker: Yurgir
127.text: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
127.context: CinematicNodeContext: Sniffs the air, then face suddenly overcome by shock and anger on 'sulphur'NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.

219.speaker: Yurgir
219.text: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
219.context: CinematicNodeContext: Explosive anger. Snarling, gesturing crossbow threateningly.NodeContext: Furious

21.speaker: Yurgir
21.text: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: I've had dealings with that devil. Maybe we can help each other.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: Perhaps I can help you escape his trap.

2.speaker: Yurgir
2.text: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.

218.speaker: Astarion
218.text: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.

28.speaker: Lae'zel
28.text: Tell him, or don't - it doesn't matter, so long as you grant me the killing blow.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: Let's share our experiences about Raphael. Perhaps we can help each other.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.

24.speaker: Yurgir
24.text: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.
24.context: NodeContext: Menacing - 'You think you can negotiate?' Pronunciation: kah-rah-TOOR

226.speaker: Yurgir
226.text: Besides, I told you already - I'm bound to this place.

144.speaker: Yurgir
144.text: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.

114.speaker: Yurgir
114.text: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: Show me this contract. Perhaps there's something you missed.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: You're hardly free as it is, trapped here. Maybe you're better off indebted to Raphael.

246.speaker: Yurgir
246.text: You wouldn't say that if you truly knew his mind. Just listen to the terms he gave me.
246.context: NodeContext: Terse, foreboding. 'You've no idea what you're talking about'

136.speaker: Player
136.text: The likes of you is frightened of a contract? I find that hard to swallow.

222.speaker: Yurgir
222.text: Maybe you'll find a crossbow bolt down your throat easier to manage.
222.context: NodeContext: Offended/aggressive at the player's insinuation he's unduly concerned about his contract.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: I happen to be an expert in such deals - and there is always a loophole.

39.speaker: Yurgir
39.text: Raphael is no foolish story-devil, his mind is different. Sneaky. Listen...

112.speaker: Yurgir
112.text:
Spill all the blood sworn to the night.
Silence all prayers; smother each rite.
112.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon sings to the player.NodeContext: singing, a cappella

170.speaker: Yurgir
170.text:
Wander Shar's halls; hungry to slay;
Leave no Justiciar alive to obey.
170.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon sings to the player.NodeContext: singing, a cappella

33.speaker: Yurgir
33.text:
Leave none to hear it, then be set free;
This song is your oath, swear, swear it to me.
33.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon sings to the player.NodeContext: singing, a cappella

91.speaker: Narrator
91.text: *Well, that explains where all the Dark Justiciars went.*

237.speaker: Narrator
237.text: *A fey giggle sounds in the back of your mind - seems as though your patron enjoys a tricksy contract.*

215.speaker: Narrator
215.text: *Especially one with a built-in loophole. The song's last couplet is a clause that's near impossible to fulfil.*

34.speaker: Narrator
34.text: *The final lyrics linger in your mind. There is a trick buried within them - a clause that cannot easily be fulfilled.*
34.context: InternalNodeContext: This node only if the player passes a passive check or if they are a bard.

19.speaker: Yurgir
19.context: CinematicNodeContext: Slight smile as he considers the player, as if he's realised something.NodeContext: A little knowing (double meaning in 'that's it' - the song has ended, but he also thinks he's stumbled upon a revelation in the lyrics.)

60.speaker: Astarion
60.text: So he's the one who slaughtered the Justiciars - we can kill him now?

105.speaker: Astarion
105.text: Because if he doesn't die, then Raphael won't tell me a damn thing about my scars.

231.speaker: Lae'zel
231.text: He killed Shar's faithful? Then he's due our congratulations before we butcher him.

217.speaker: Shadowheart
217.text: So he's responsible for the carnage down here. All those Dark Justiciars... slaughtered.
217.context: NodeContext: Cool anger followed by a slight note of mournfulness as she realises she's facing the creature that killed many Shar followers

11.speaker: Karlach
11.text: Not surprised this guy stomped all those Dark Justiciars. It's what orthons do.

117.speaker: Yurgir
117.text: Parchment can burn. Oral agreements aren't worth the tongues they're waggled out upon. A song lingers.

16.speaker: Yurgir
16.text: Raphael made double-sure of that: I can't forget the damned thing so long as my work's not finished.

29.speaker: Yurgir
29.text: I did as instructed, but the song still rattles about in my head - the contract still stands, somehow. If I break it, I will become Raphael's slave forever.

37.speaker: Yurgir
37.text: Anyway, enough prattle. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.
37.context: CinematicNodeContext: Tilts his head and looks at the player, as if appraising them.NodeContext: Brutally matter-of-fact

48.speaker: Yurgir
48.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raises his crossbow and points it at the player.

243.speaker: Narrator
243.text: *You feel your patron's prickling flame at the back of your mind - and its diabolic words on your tongue. It wants to help.*

120.speaker: Player
120.text: It's Raphael you want, not me.

185.speaker: Yurgir
185.text: I'll have both, if I wish.
185.context: NodeContext: Growled retort. 'Don't tell me what I want'

73.speaker: Player
73.text: Wait - there's one last Dark Justiciar. I met him.

201.speaker: Yurgir
201.text: Don't insult me - I'd know if there was a Justiciar down there.

97.speaker: Yurgir
97.text: But go on - spill some blood, prove me wrong. If there truly is a Justiciar, the song will end and you will be vindicated.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: All right, leave it to me.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: I'm not your errand-runner, or your butcher.

248.speaker: Player
248.text: Do I look like I'm offering charity? What will you give me in return?

13.speaker: Yurgir
13.text: Haggling. A grubby little trait. Fine, there's a gem I keep over by my bed. Kill the Justiciar, and it's yours.

53.speaker: Yurgir
53.text: Go on then. But if you're lying - if you run - there'll be nowhere that's safe for you.

244.speaker: Yurgir
244.text: I'll spare your life - that's ample reward.
244.context: NodeContext: 'Be happy with your lot, or else'

235.speaker: Player
235.text: There's a necromancer called Balthazar elsewhere in the temple - perhaps he's the one you need to kill.

206.speaker: Yurgir
206.text: I caught the scent of that bloated carcass already - he's no more alive than the Dark Justiciars down here.

254.speaker: Yurgir
254.text: No. He is not the answer. He is not my prey.

139.speaker: Player
139.text: There must be something you missed. Let me search this place for you.

164.speaker: Yurgir
164.text: I spent a century roaming these halls - I spilled every drop of Dark Justiciar blood that there was to spill. And you think you can do better?
164.context: NodeContext: Menacing. Drawing out the moment.

233.speaker: Yurgir
233.text: Go on then - I'll enjoy watching you fail. But try to run, and you will regret it.
233.context: NodeContext: Sardonic. Doesn't favour the player's chances. Tenday = in-universe period of time.

245.speaker: Yurgir
245.text: I may be trapped here, but I'm not without friends. If you break your word, they'll hunt you down and make your final moments a symphony of agony.

247.speaker: Yurgir
247.text: I already have plenty of lackeys. All you have to offer me is your death.

228.speaker: Player
228.text: The lyrics are a trick. You've always had an audience - your followers. Get rid of them.

106.speaker: Yurgir
106.text: The merregons? They barely have a thought to share among themselves... but they do have ears.

135.speaker: Yurgir
135.text: Kill yourselves - back to the hells with you.
135.context: NodeContext: Addressing the merregons. Matter of fact, like he's telling them they can clock off early.

150.context: CinematicNodeContext: The merregons pair off, facing each other. Each one simultaneously raises their halberd against the other, then swing. Cut to the player reacting to the moment of impact, heard off-screen.

45.speaker: Yurgir
45.text: I still hear it. Seems your theory is wrong.
45.context: CinematicNodeContext: Cocks his head slightly, as if listening to something, then glares at the player.NodeContext: Temper building. Thinks he's been dupped.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Displacer hearing is notoriously sharp. You must kill her too.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: You're not finished yet - the displacer can hear you, can't she? Kill her.

180.speaker: Yurgir
180.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon looks at the displacer, who gazes back at him with an adoring purr.NodeContext: Hesitant

5.speaker: Yurgir
5.context: CinematicNodeContext: Levels his crossbow at the displacerNodeContext: Solemn

258.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon shoots the displacer with his crossbow.

190.speaker: Yurgir
190.context: CinematicNodeContext: Orthon drops his crossbow and produces a sword from behind his waist.NodeContext: Seething, murderous

230.speaker: Player
230.text: Exactly. Kill yourself, complete the contract, and you'll be reborn in Avernus. Free.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: Kill yourself, coward. Then you'll return to Avernus. You'll be free.

159.speaker: Yurgir
159.text: If you're wrong about this, I'll claw my way out of Avernus and eat you alive - contract be damned.

84.speaker: Yurgir
84.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon looks upward, as if addressing Raphael up on the surface. NodeContext: Resignation/begrudging respect.

214.context: CinematicNodeContext: The orthon turns the tip of his sword around to face himself, and rams it into his own torso. He falls dead.

94.speaker: Lae'zel
94.text: An acceptable conclusion. But it is a shame I won't know the pleasure of executing a wardevil.

122.speaker: Lae'zel
122.text: Well. There is always next time.

85.speaker: Karlach
85.text: Damn. Now there's something I never thought I'd see. Brutal.
85.context: NodeContext: Not too heartbroken, kind of bemused

239.speaker: Astarion
239.text: That was incredible - I'm actually impressed! You have a wicked little mind.
239.context: NodeContext: Emphasise each of the first three words. "That. Was. Incredible."

208.speaker: Gale
208.text: I see the art of eloquence is alive and well. I'm awed, impressed, and a little bit scared of you right now.

137.speaker: Wyll
137.text: Balduran's bones, what a performance - you'd put the Five Flagons to shame!

196.speaker: Shadowheart
196.text: That silver tongue of yours is dangerous - bravo. I can't believe you actually pulled that off...
196.context: NodeContext: Impressed. The player pulled off a very unlikely series of persuasion moments against a potential foe.

27.speaker: Astarion
27.text: Does... does that count as us killing him? That had better count.

76.speaker: Yurgir
76.text: Maybe that's true, maybe not - but I don't have to let you live in order to find out.

209.speaker: Player
209.text: My dear hunter, isn't it obvious? You must kill yourself - then you'll be free.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: Exactly. Kill yourself, complete the contract, and you'll be reborn in Avernus. Free.

224.speaker: Player
224.text: Kill yourself, coward. Then you'll return to Avernus. You'll be free.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: My dear hunter, isn't it obvious? You must kill yourself - then you'll be free.

227.speaker: Yurgir
227.text: Pathetic. A dusk hag once claimed she dreamt of a future where I spared her, but even her weaselling is no match for yours. This ends now.

256.speaker: Player
256.text: Raphael's a sly lyricist - he tricked you. Your followers heard your song and still live.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: You always hear the song, orthon. Kill yourself, be reborn in the Hells, break the contract.

198.speaker: Narrator
198.text: *Both far away and all too close, you feel your patron's grin. A job well done.*

221.speaker: Player
221.text: Wait! You might have missed something, and I'm uniquely good at tracking things down.

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Raphael wanted you to kill Dark Justiciars? Why?

123.speaker: Yurgir
123.text: Asking why doesn't get me paid - hunting and killing does. Raphael mentioned something about an aasimar. Meant nothing to me.
123.context: InternalNodeContext: Aasimar reference being a hint towards Nightsong.NodeContext: Pronounced AH-sim-ar.

152.speaker: Yurgir
152.text: I did my part - I filled these halls with ghosts. But Raphael's playing some other game - one that involves stiffing me.

234.speaker: Yurgir
234.text: It's been some time since I had an audience. Any who hear it tend to die.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: That was awful - perhaps you should stick to killing.

193.speaker: Yurgir
193.text: Oh, I intend to. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Quite bloodthirsty, as lyrics go. Have you considered some instrumental accompaniment?

174.speaker: Yurgir
174.text: I don't want to make it pretty - I want to silence it.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: Shar is not my goddess, but I can respect her. I ought to kill you for what you have done to her temple.

191.speaker: Yurgir
191.text: Ought you? The Dark Justiciars all failed - and made the most interesting noises as they died. Some even called out to other gods for help...

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Then they failed her, and you never met a true servant of Shar.

63.speaker: Yurgir
63.text: What, they're no longer worth avenging? You're a fickle creature, little Sharran.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: A deception. The Dark Lady would approve of them trying to sway you.

104.speaker: Yurgir
104.text: You give them too much credit. And show more spine than they did - at least until I flayed them.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: You blaspheme this holy place. I must strike you down.

6.speaker: Yurgir
6.text: Bold of you. Stupid, but bold.
6.context: NodeContext: Dry. Not overly concerned that the player's about to attack (combat ensues after this line)

116.speaker: Player
116.text: Shar is not my goddess, but I can respect her. I ought to kill you for what you have done to her temple.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: You desecrated Shar's temple? You slew her children? I ought to kill you.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: A pact made from song? Quite quaint for a devil, I must say.

207.speaker: Astarion
207.text: Pretty tune for a contract that says 'kill all Justiciars'.

241.speaker: Wyll
241.text: So this was the wardevil who slaughtered Shar's faithful. At Raphael's urging, no less.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: So he's the one who killed all the Dark Justiciars. Alone. Might not want to get on his bad side.

20.speaker: Karlach
20.text: Not surprised this guy single-handedly wiped out the Dark Justiciars here. Fucker is stacked.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: Diabolic deals in legend always have loopholes - we just need to find it.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: Raphael is a devil like all your kind - he deals in tricks. You probably missed a loophole in your contract.

177.speaker: Yurgir
177.text: If you won't speak, then you don't need to draw breath. Tell me what I want, or I'll feed you to my pet over a tenday, and keep you alive to watch.

232.speaker: Player
232.text: I've got nothing to spit out - not for you, anyway.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: Help me with my infernal engine, and I'll tell you.

47.speaker: Yurgir
47.text: I deal in blood and bones - not cogs and wrenches. Tell me what I wish to know, or you'll find that out first hand.

236.speaker: Shadowheart
236.text: Careful -  I'm not sure we want Raphael as an enemy.

153.speaker: Karlach
153.text: We piss off a devil no matter what we do. Pick your poison - we'll handle the fallout like we always do.

74.speaker: Astarion
74.text: Well? Tell him. We owe the devil nothing.

163.speaker: Wyll
163.text: Go on, tell the bastard. All the better for us if he keeps Raphael - busy.

61.speaker: Gale
61.text: While two devils fight over a bone - well, we should just run away and let them sort it among themselves.

204.speaker: Karlach
204.text: I'm not one to placate a devil, but the last thing we need is an orthon for an enemy. Fought one once, and my back has never been the same.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: There's nothing stopping you from leaving. I know a way out.

167.speaker: Yurgir
167.text: Hah! There's my word. I agreed to a contract - one that hasn't yet been fulfilled.
167.context: NodeContext: Sardonic. Short, bitter bark of a laugh at the start.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: No trap is inescapable, trust me.

22.speaker: Yurgir
22.text: Hah! Perhaps this is true of the mundane traps you know. But I am held here by something stronger.

12.speaker: Yurgir
12.text: Words. A contract penned by that deceitful slug Raphael.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: I don't know what you mean.

253.speaker: Yurgir
253.text: Lies! My nose would recognise him anywhere.

172.speaker: Player
172.text: I'd never ally myself with such a fiend.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: I don't keep company with devils.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: The devil has been stalking my companions - what dealings do you have with him?

132.speaker: Yurgir
132.text: Stupid rabbit. Running can't save you.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Well, allow me to hop to it - I want to talk.

240.speaker: Player
240.text: If I was burrowing, you'd never find me.

176.speaker: Yurgir
176.text: I would sniff you out in an instant. Prey like you always has a most distinctive scent, it's like...

109.speaker: Player
109.text: This 'rabbit' has hunted prey larger than you. I suggest you choose your next words wisely.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I'll burrow my fist into your chest if you don't stop mouthing off.

42.speaker: Yurgir
42.text: You are mouthy, little rabbit. This will be -
42.context:
NodeContext: Scornful, but then breaks off before finishing the line
(Full version would be 'This will be over quickly'' if he'd finished it)

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Your words thrum with violence. Peace - let us speak.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: My apologies. Try as I might, the surface-stink just won't wash off.

261.speaker: Yurgir
261.text: I smell the depths below that is true, but...

88.speaker: Player
88.text: I may stink of the surface, but it's not where I hail from.

220.speaker: Yurgir
220.text: You are star-touched that is true, but...

35.speaker: Yurgir
35.text: Oh no, little rabbit. You don't get to just hop away.
